items.title: CPU instruction "pext" as a flag?
items.body: Using the latest version of `py-cpuinfo 7.0.0`, I didn't get the CPU instruction `pext` listed as a flag. Does the flag `pext` shows up if this instruction is present in the CPU? Anyone with a newer CPU, please check this.

items.title: Change 'byte code' to 'machine code'
items.body: I've been saying "byte code" and "machine code" interchangeably. Byte code runs in a VM. Machine code runs on a CPU. Change it to "machine code".

items.title: Remove extended_model and extended_family fields
items.body: It is a good idea to remove these fields as they are only used internally to calculate the actual Family and Model.

items.title: CPUID family and model is wrong
items.body:
We aren't calculating the CPU Model and Family correctly. It looks like we need to combine the Extended Model with Model and Extended Family with Family:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPUID#EAX.3D1:_Processor_Info_and_Feature_Bits

items.title: Cache fields should be full ints instead of kb strings
items.body:
For example, change "32 KB" to 32768.

Some cache fields are in KB, and some in B. All should be bytes.

```
L1 Data Cache Size: 32K # Convert to bytes
L1 Instruction Cache Size: 78K # Convert to bytes
L2 Cache Size: 4096 KB # Convert to bytes
L2 Cache Line Size: 512 # Is bytes already
L2 Cache Associativity: 0x6L # Remove hex format
L3 Cache Size: 16384 KB # Convert to bytes
```

items.title: Remove empty and zeroed fields.
items.body: Some internal functions may return empty or zeroed fields. Such as `_get_cpu_info_from_proc_cpuinfo` sometimes returning `(0, 0)` for `"hz_advertised"`. Then when `_get_cpu_info_from_cpuid` tries to set the field `"hz_advertised"` to `(3693000000, 0)`, it will see that it is already set, and not change it. Then we end up with `(0, 0)`. We should also filter out fields that contain: `None, 0, "", (), {}, [], (0, 0)`.

items.title: The get_cache function has swapped fields
items.body:
https://github.com/workhorsy/py-cpuinfo/blob/63931cb6b6b13b23b8ea5def60c5560cf7af6856/cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py#L1213-L1217 

The wikipedia source (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPUID#EAX=80000006h:_Extended_L2_Cache_Features) used for the function mentions the bits for the ECX register are line size (07-00), associativity (15-12), and then cache size (31-16), but the implementation has it ordered as cache size, line size, and then associativity.

items.title: On non BeOS systems, calling sysinfo may open GUI program
items.body:
When calling cpuinfo.get_cpu_info() this package seems to try to run the command `sysinfo -cpu` if it finds that such a command is available. This is not a default package on Ubuntu 18.04 but after installing the package sysinfo using `sudo apt install sysinfo`, there is a script called `/usr/bin/sysinfo`
This script invokes a mono program `mono Sysinfo.exe` which seems to ignore all command line arguments. 
The GUI shows the following about information:
"Sysinfo 0.7 Copyright Nil Gradisnik 2006 <ghaefb@gmail.com>"
http://sourceforge.net/projects/gsysinfo

Since this GUI program is invoked, the call to `get_cpu_info()` hangs until the GUI is terminated.
Since this package is used in a number of other tools and packages, this is a real problem on systems where the "sysinfo" package is installed.

* CPU architecture x86_64
* Operating System Ubuntu 18.04
* Python version 3.6.8
* Version of py-cpuinfo 5.0.0

items.title: Overhead from generating machine code throws off CPUID HZ
items.body:
The way we are getting the HZ is off, because of the overhead from setting up the byte code for each call to get_ticks.

~~~python
start = self.get_ticks() # Rebuilds the byte code and function
time.sleep(1)
end = self.get_ticks() # Rebuilds the byte code and function
ticks = (end - start)
~~~

Change it to be more like



~~~python
# Generate get_ticks_x86 first
func = self.get_ticks_func() # Rebuilds the byte code and function

start = func()
time.sleep(1)
end = func()
ticks = (end - start)

func.free()
~~~

items.title: Make test suite also check SELinux
items.body: The test suite is not checking for selinux. It is just assuming that it is not running. The way we are checking is also not testable, because it is run and checked in one function. Break it into a one function that runs sestatus, and one function that checks the result.

items.title: Add option to return --version
items.body:
Make it return the version like:

~~~bash
python3 cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py --version
~~~

items.title: Rename fields to be more clear
items.body:
Change Hz fields to be normal (3000000, 0) and friendly ("3.0000 Mhz").

Change all fields that are read from the CPU to end with "raw".

items.title: Make unit tests also test CPUID
items.body: We should include mock data from the CPUID register. That way we can test that too.

items.title: Missing info on Windows 10 Ryzen 7 X86_64
items.body: Lots of info is missing. Like Hz, stepping, family, and model.

items.title: Remove PyInstaller hacks
items.body:
In order to get py-cpuinfo to work on Windows with PyInstaller, we are using some monkey patches to fake support for fork. Putting these hacks inside py-cpuinfo was a bad idea because:

1. I don't want to set a precedence of including custom code, to make py-cpuinfo work with bugs in external libraries.
2. This seems to be fixed in new versions of PyInstaller.
3. This requires us to also include freeze support inside py-cpuinfo. Without the hack, the freeze can be performed in the client program that uses py-cpuinfo.

https://github.com/pyinstaller/pyinstaller/wiki/Recipe-Multiprocessing

items.title: Client script runs multiple times without __main__
items.body:
The following script reproduces the problem:

```
import cpuinfo
cpuinfo.get_cpu_info()
print 'How many times should I see this?'
```

gives output

```
How many times should I see this?
How many times should I see this?
```

I believe the problem was introduced in https://github.com/workhorsy/py-cpuinfo/commit/9bbd7fb8adb30c1cfb4389dd696a758d9d1f172f and is because the function ``_get_cpu_info_from_cpuid`` uses multiprocessing (which is problematic on Windows).

I need to generate a PY script to get these details for asses management.

Thank You
Syed Hussaini
email: syed.hussaini11@outlook.com

items.title: Hello!!
items.body:
# In your bug report please include:
* CPU architecture
* Operating System
* Python version
* Version of py-cpuinfo

items.title: Missing Git tags for releases
items.body: It would be nice to keep PyPI releases and git tags in sync :)

items.title: Parsing Haiku sysinfo fails
items.body: It looks like the formatting of sysinfo -cpu has changed a little? Check that it works on x86 and x86_64 with old and new Haiku.

items.title: Officially drop support for Python 2.6
items.body: Some places and docs say py-cpuinfo works on python 2.6. But it does not anymore. So update everything to say that it supports 2.7 and 3.x.

items.title: Replace duplicate platform.system calls with function
items.body: Remove the DataSource.is_windows method and add DataSource.os_type method from helpers. This way we can remove all the little hacks that call platform.system and only partially parse the result.

items.title: Only check dmesg boot log on Linux
items.body: Parsing the kernel boot log for CPU information keeps breaking on Solaris and BSD.

items.title: Include Python version in output
items.body: todo

items.title: Include if Python is 32 or 64 bit in get_system_info
items.body:
Something like this would be fine:

```
sys.maxsize:
===============================================================================
2147483647 (32 bit)
```

https://docs.python.org/3/library/platform.html#cross-platform

items.title: Fails to detect winreg imported as _winreg in get_system_info
items.body:
It looks like even if we do:

```python
import _winreg as winreg
```

It shows up as "_winreg" instead of "winreg" in sys modules.

So this fails:

```python
if 'winreg' in sys.modules:
   ...

```

items.title: Get Windows CPU info with wmic
items.body:
Something like:

```
wmic cpu
```

items.title: lscpu gets brand field twice
items.body:
We do this twice in a row when parsing lscpu info:

```python
		brand = _get_field(False, output, None, None, 'Model name')
		if brand:
			info['brand'] = brand

		brand = _get_field(False, output, None, None, 'Model name')
		if brand:
			info['brand'] = brand
```

items.title: Change version number format
items.body: Right now our version numbers are 0.API_change.features. It should be changed to API_change.features.bug_fixes. So the current version of 0.2.7 would become 2.7.0

items.title: Combine data from all sources instead of picking one
items.body: Right now it picks data from the first source that returns something. The problem with this, is that each source only provides a few fields. If we get data from all the sources, we can combine all the fields. This should also remove coupling between data sources.

items.title: conda package (on conda-forge)
items.body:
Since py-cpuinfo is a pure Python package, installation is of course not a big issue. However, some packages that have compiled C-extensions (like one of ours) might depend on it and those now often tend to provide conda packages to make installation easier. Only conda packages can be dependencies of conda packages, so that's why we created a conda package for py-cpuinfo on anaconda.org (https://anaconda.org/brian-team/py-cpuinfo) -- judging from the number of downloads, it's quite popular!
What do you think of having a package on conda-forge (http://conda-forge.github.io/) instead? I'd be happy to create the package recipe (again, for a pure Python package this is rather trivial) and I could list you and me as maintainers (or only you or only me if you prefer).

items.title: Only works after commenting out the _get_hz_string_from_beagle_bone() part
items.body:
get_cpu_info() always returned None. Some debugging showed that the line 

```
hz_brand = output.split('current CPU frequency is')[1].split('.')[0].lower()
```

in `_get_hz_string_from_beagle_bone` throws an error. In `get_cpu_info_from_proc_cpuinfo` I commented the following block out

```
# Try getting the Hz for a BeagleBone
        if hz_advertised == '0.0':
            scale, hz_advertised = _get_hz_string_from_beagle_bone()
            hz_actual = hz_advertised
```

After that it worked.

items.body: In Virtual Box some operating systems will segfault when CPUID calls ctypes.pythonapi.memmove. These include BSD, Cygwin, OSX, and Solaris. But Windows, Linux, and BeOS work.

items.title: get_cpu_info_from_cpuid breaks with Python3
items.body: Querying the CPUID register is broken in Python3

items.title: Make test suite test real functions too
items.body: We have a problem where the test suite will work correctly with the mock objects. But fail with the real objects. So lets test the real thing too.

items.title: Add basic documentation
items.body:
The readme.md page has a lot of duplicate info, and is missing a lot:
- Remove second giant example output
- Explain the structure of the retuned info object
- Add `python -m cpuinfo` to list of ways to use it
- Add a list of API calls and what they do
- Add a list of supported OSes and their status

items.title: Please ship tests to pypi

milestone.description: This release will have some API changes. So I will bump the minor version number.

items.body: Downstream developers love to test during their packaging efforts. PLease include the tests in your pypi tarball.

items.title: Missing AVX2 CPU flag on OS X
items.body: Apologies for the naive question, but will this package detect support for AVX2 instructions?

items.title: Remove has_blah methods
items.body: Instead of having both a has_blah() and blah() method. Just check if blah() exists. This will prevent errors where we forget to have both setup.

items.title: System exit called if CPU is not supported
items.body:
Hi,

i use py-cpuinfo in the Glances project (https://github.com/nicolargo/glances). On Raspberry Pi, if the CPU is not supported, Py-Cpuinfo call an (ugly) sys.exit(0) (https://github.com/workhorsy/py-cpuinfo/blob/master/cpuinfo/cpuinfo.py#L1478). It should be more "Pythonific" to raise an error.

Thanks in advance for the enhancement.

items.body:
We are missing the "Features2", "AMD Features", and "AMD Features2" CPU flags.

``` raw

===============================================================================
CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4440 CPU @ 3.10GHz (2993.39-MHz K8-class CPU)
  Origin = "GenuineIntel"  Id = 0x306c3  Family = 0x6  Model = 0x3c  Stepping = 3
  Features=0x78bfbff<FPU,VME,DE,PSE,TSC,MSR,PAE,MCE,CX8,APIC,SEP,MTRR,PGE,MCA,CMOV,PAT,PSE36,CLFLUSH,MMX,FXSR,SSE,SSE2>
  Features2=0x209<SSE3,MON,SSSE3>
```

items.title: CPUID breaks on brands with many NULL terminators
items.body:
We were assuming that all brand strings ended on one NULL terminator. But some have more:

"Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-4300U CPU @ 1.90GHz           "

This causes a crash on such systems.

items.title: CPUID failure segfaults Python
items.body: If something goes wrong when running the CPUID byte code, it crashes Python. We need to try running it is a subprocess to fix the problem.

items.title: Check if some return codes need to be converted
items.body:
Check if some return codes need to be converted:

``` python
import os

rc = process.returncode
if hasattr(os, 'WIFEXITED') and os.WIFEXITED(rc):
    rc = os.WEXITSTATUS(rc)
```

We were doing this before. This may not be needed anymore. Make sure. Check this:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1535672/how-to-interpret-status-code-in-python-commands-getstatusoutput

items.title: Getting CPU info from dmesg fails on Linux but not BSD
items.body: It looks like there are 2 versions of dmesg, one that takes an "-a" argument, and one that does not. Plus they are formatted a little differently on Linux and BSD.

items.title: Subprocess stderr is sometimes printed to console
items.body:
Change this:
p1 = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE)

to this:
p1 = subprocess.Popen(command, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)

items.title: Add a test suite
items.body:
Extract all the things that get cpu info into a DataSource object. Like:
DataSource.has_kstat
DataSource.kstat_m_cpu_info
DataSource.has_proc_cpuinfo
DataSource.proc_cpuinfo

That way we can override the methods to return hard coded strings. This will make it easier to test on different platforms.

items.title: Make a script for easy gathering of CPU info
items.body:
The script should gather:

From Python:
sys.version_info
multiprocessing.cpu_count()
platform.uname()
platform.architecture()
platform.system()
platform.machine()

output of commands:
cpufreq-info
sestatus -b
dmesg -a
cat /proc/cpuinfo
sysctl machdep.cpu
isainfo -vb
kstat -m cpu_info

items.title: Make it work on Raspberry Pi
items.body:
See the commands to get the Hz:

``` bash
cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_max_freq
cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_min_freq
cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_cur_freq
```

items.title: Make it work on a BeagleBone
items.body: We can get the Hz from the cpufreq-info command.

items.title: Makefile is hard coded for python 2
items.body: Update the Makefile so it can work with python3 too.

items.title: On Windows use win32 cpuid function instead of registry
items.body: The Windows registry is missing newer flags like sse3, et cetera. See if we can use Python ctypes to call the win32 cpuid function instead.

items.title: Importing is different depending on install method

milestone.description: This release will have some API changes. So I will bump the minor version number.

items.body:
If you install with pip or setup.py you have to do:

from cpuinfo import cpuinfo

to get the cpuinfo module. This is because the module cpuinfo is in a package called cpuinfo.

If you import directly from the cpuinfo.py file (as in you copied the file directly into your project). You can import like this:

import cpuinfo

This is super confusing. How do we make this consistent? I would prefer to do "import cpuinfo"

items.title: It is not obvious if Hz Raw is the current Hz, or the advertised Hz
items.body:
We should have a tuple for the current Hz, and the advertised Hz:

```
hz_actual: 800 MHz
hz_advertised: 1.6000 GHz
hz_current_raw: (8000000, 0)
hz_actual_raw: (1600000000, 0)
```

This way we can use the numbers in comparisons.

items.title: Wrong CPU frequency in get_cpu_info_from_proc_cpuinfo()
items.body: On line 867 of cpuinfo.py `processor_hz` is set to `'01612.0'` which overwrites the actual processor frequency. Why did you do that?
